comments.commentBody:
Or even as much? We really need information on what is good and, thus, on what and whom to vote for instead of what to vote against.

In the same vein of reporting what matters, where is the outrage in our press about the Adelson GOP show of sycophancy that took place in that haven of psychological wellness, Las Vegas. This question, with accompanying outrage, was put to me by a Canadian friend.

@Editorial Board:  How about devoting half as much analysis to the Progressive Caucus's budget?  It actually makes sense, unlike Ryan's, which literally makes no sense except as experimental fiction (no plot, no characters, no facts).

Saw the video or the most disgusting part of it. This man (Boyd), mentally ill or not, was not a threat to the police that were at quite a distance from him. If there was awareness that he had a mental illness why wasn't a trained professional called in? Was camping where he was such a crime that his murder is supposed to be justified? Wasn't he someone's son or brother? In the video, the police look like cold blooded killers! I don't think there is any way to justify what they did. There may be a law on the books in NM or some other state that attempts to do so, but the actions of law enforcement in this video appear to exhibit a reality that violated every right Boyd had. When he said he couldn't move and asked them not to hurt him anymore-- once he was down after he had been shot in the back, they continued to inflict wounds upon him. The threat and violence here was perpetrated by the police: despicable. I hope they are all charged with a crime! And, when they walk, that the memory of killing this young man haunts them everyday. Wake up, America! When your weakest have to fear your strongest there is plenty of trouble coming. The threat is the militarization of the police!

In all fairness, firearms are not as pervasive as in the USA, but knifes or other weapons are just as readily available. The distinction should be made between someone wielding a firearm and someone who does not.

Even so, illegal firearms, usually from the East, are also readily available in Germany and they are used by criminals in a fair number of cases. Still, the statistics show that German police knows how to defuse such stand-offs without the need to kill.

So, why are our cops so incompetent then? Or is it more than incompetence?

These policemen in the video were clearly hunting. They were not peace officers. That gentleman did not wield his small pocket-sized knives until the dog lunged toward him. How would you respond to a police dog lunging towards you? This is shameful.

The police in the small city in which I did my psychiatry residency had special training for dealing with mental illness and responding to crises involving these patients. It made a huge difference. It would be great if such training could be more universal.

"There was a time when we were a compassionate nation"

Phooey. You mean pre-slavery or post-slavery? Surely you must be referring to the long period during which we built this nation on the blood of the natives.

There was a time when we were a compassionate nation, then Ronald Regan came along and glorified the wealthy and demonized the poor and the mentally ill. The Party of Regan has brought us the New America where we dispose of the poor and the mentally ill once they are no longer useful to be preyed upon by the trickle down crowd. We have exchanged empathy, compassion and charity for greed, hate and fear. We are a nation in rapid decline and deservedly so.
"THANK gosh!"...

Paul Ryan is relatively well to do, but really NOTHING compared to John Kerry and the Heinz fortune. Or the Kennedy's billions. Or Al Gore (long line of inherited wealth).

I'll bet that even the Clintons could buy and sell Paul Ryan.

Why do those folks get a pass from you, but Ryan gets ridiculed for his money? Do you know any genuinely poor people serving in Congress? Can you name them?

Paul Ryan had a dream the other night in which he came home from D.C. to find that his entire family had been slaughtered and all of his possessions cleaned out.  Awakening with a scream, he was asked by his wife what the problem was.  "That gosh!," he replied.  "I dreamed I was poor!"

Agreed.  As a person with two mentally ill siblings, I understand and empathize with what you are saying.  I became a mental health professional in part to better equip myself to deal with their behaviors since we cannot even mandate an assessment  unless very strict criteria are met.  My sister did not really get the help she needed until she did something dangerous, and my brother has been unmedicated and unable to work for the past decade (but this is his "choice").  So sad.

I am from Albuquerque and have a mentally ill sibling, so this article hit particularly close to home.  I have witnessed my sibling being cyclically thrown into one of two places: the community hospital for at most two nights (which can cost in the thousands of dollars by the way), or in jail if  a crime had been committed. Truthfully, the only respite my family has been afforded is those long jail stays.  Many imply it the family's failure in taking care of their mentally ill relatives that has lead to the homelessness and violence associated with mental illness.  But, I have learned that as a family member you don't have the medical expertise necessary to heal, or at minimum control, these issues.  Though the healthcare system had ultimate faults in the past, the systematic deconstruction of long term psychiatric care created an undue burden on our families, the general public, and in the case of this article the police.  We need affordable or free long-term care and living services that protects the public and mentally ill individuals; especially from predatory police officers.  There should be no justifiable reason why a man, with a clear history of illness, is living exposed in the foothills of the Sandia Mountains.  Though the final and ultimate blame lies with the unrestrained officers that shot James Boyd in the back when he didn't pose a true threat (I urge you to watch the full video), we as a society needed to support him in his life.

We have to decide whether we want a society that provides for the"general welfare" or not.

Right now, it appears that the biggest task before us is how to nake the richest people richer.

We might want to revisit our priorities.

Closing the State Hospitals required a bipartisan effort:
the ACLU and other hand-wringers couldn't stand for people to be "warehoused" (despite the fact that that is all many need), and the GOP beancounters didn't want to pay for them in the first place.

The only options aren't institutionalization vs. de-instututionalization. Treatment in community has long been the preferred method. Halfway houses, outpatient therapy, day inpatient therapy, etc., are often more useful because they teach people how to live in the real world. The problem has always been funding. At one point in time we locked up mentally ill people and forgot about them. Now we don't but we still refuse to pay for the treatment that will allow them to become productive members of society.
@D:  In SF, funding is not an issue.  Instead, it is well known here that the mentally ill who are homeless do not want to engage in outpatient therapy and do not want to live in halfway houses.

Whether it's in prisons, on the streets, or in asylums, America's treatment of the mentally ill has never been ideal. Though de-institutionalization resulted in a lot of bad outcomes, one thing it was meant to prevent was the isolation of people who already experience a mental environment that leaves them acutely alienated. We can say that re-institutionalization is what we need, but who's to say that the pendulum won't swing in another 30 or 40 years and we won't find ourselves arguing for de-institutionalization once again? As the daughter of two mentally ill parents, I find it painful to hear how simplistic peoples' responses are to the question of how to care for the mentally ill. We are not just talking about individuals or even just families. It's important to recognize that mental health is a community issue, and that the mental health of all of the people directly involved in this particular situation, including the easily vilifiable officers, is at stake.

We are nowhere near Abq, but what's on the video is simply shocking. People outside of NM probably weren't aware of how much trouble one of the shooting officers was in before APD, and it's amazing that he was hired. The man was fired by New Mexico state police, under criminal indictment and prosecution. None the less, he was hired by the Abq police brass, which caused quite an uproar. The APD chief at the time said we just hire him to do paper work, he will just be in the office, he will never have a badge or a gun.. Ya, really??
For the full story: http://krqe.com/2014/03/19/cop-involved-in-sunday-shooting-had-rocky-pas...

Dear JHM,
While people on marijuana are often irrational, they are almost never violent, the drug has a somewhat soporific, soothing effect. It may be beneficial in that people won't use meth, crack, cocaine, LSD, PCP's, and other harder drugs as much, because all of those do make people violent.

This will only get worse with so many states, including New York, wanting or vowing to legalize marijuana.  Perhaps this will not cause more to use drugs like marijuana (although sadly more and more in the pupulation will), perhaps they will use this anyhow, as too many do now, but more and more confrontations will occur and I pity the police.  How can they cope with this?  How do you talk to an irrational, armed person?  How will the society cope?  We have cancelled so much of what was in place - once.  And there are just too many in this country who cannot live within the "normal" framework of society.  Delusional, refusing any psychiatric intervention -- this just gets worse.

What a great country eh? But we're never at a loss for enough funds for war.

I watched the video footage from the cop's helmet. This was plain murder. Sickening.

The NYT has done nothing wrong.  Gun ownership by the mentally ill.  Another problem that will only worsen, thanks to the NRA and all the States and Legislators who also want to legalize marijuana now.

A symptom of America turning into a police state. It is amazing to see all the militaristic armed responses and swat teams in response to many ordinary crimes that lead to the use of unnecessary force - shootings, injuries, and death.

A lot of this has to do with internalizing 911, and all the dollars that have flowed into creating "homeland" security.

Do American police fire warning shots…?

(maybe only in the movies)
Sorry folks, just a case of mistaken identity. Clearly the police officers thought James Boyd was Oscar Grant.

One doesn't even need to review the school transcripts or resumes of our police forces to know that the overall IQ level of most cops is very low.  The newest recruits all clearly come from poor uneducated backgrounds and see the police force as an 'easy' job to get.
Just remember also that these mentally ill people can probably obtain guns quite easily. since this country so reveres the Second Amendment.

Oh My God. That film brought me to tears and shame and fear. And we talk about human rights and police abuses in China and Russia and Cuba? We are hypocrites.
That was cold blooded murder (of a person of color) by 6, 8, 10 heavily armed white men. The victim with his 2 little knives was no threat to them. Each should be tried for murder and go to jail.
I am disgusted and ashamed, but what do you expect in a country that has turned prisons into a for-profit industry? And that still uses capital punishment? And that does not take care of its mentally ill and believes the solution to violence is arming more people?
How sad.

I've dealt with the mentally ill in group homes for many years and there are numerous techniques for "de-escalating"  an individual's behavior. For example, re-directing him to another subject that catches his attention. It's remarkable how the "bad" behavior can end instantly. I must point out though, that I work in a controlled setting with people I've known for weeks, months or years. The police don't operate with that luxury. I pity both them and the confused men they encounter.

There is nothing more dangerous than a uniform, specially one with ensignia and decorations, purportedly to enforce the law with arms - at home or abroad. It makes ordinary mortals believe they are gods.

As the world gets uglier and more difficult to cope with I expect that more folks will fall by the wayside, shot by police, dying in a ditch from inattention, freezing in the cold, and dying in the heat.

In Vancouver a couple of years ago during a heat wave, a homeless mentally ill person, who was well known to the health system (but did not have a home or adequate treatment) died of hyperthermia and dehydration lying in a public park where hundreds of people walk by each day.

A homeless, mentally ill woman incinerated herself on a cold winter night with a candle in her 'home', a shopping cart.

A man suffering a psychotic episode decapitated the fellow sitting next to him on the long distance bus.

We don't like to think that children or the elderly don't receive the health care they need in a timely fashion, we don't like it when we can't get that gall bladder or knee operation right away when we are pain.

Why is there still this dichotomy in recognizing the pain and cost to society from mental illness? This is the 21st century. We don't burn witches anymore, but things don't seem to have come very far.

Mental illness causes so much pain to those who suffer from it, their families, and the larger society.

But, those are the 'others' who suffer. Why spend our hard earned dollars? Don't want tax and spend,
